question: In cancer cells, does inhibiting glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase promote lipogenesis by deactivating LKB1-AMPK signaling? Answer with Yes or No.

content.source_1: 6PGD-mediated production of ribulose-5-phosphate (Ru-5-P) inhibits AMPK activation by disrupting the active LKB1 complex, thereby activating acetyl-CoA carboxylase 1 and lipogenesis.
content.source_2: Short-term pharmacologic inhibition of glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase in primary hepatocytes suppressed LKB1-AMPK signaling and increased ACC1 activity, resulting in a significant rise in de novo lipogenesis.
content.source_3: We found that suppression of 6PGD decreased lipogenesis and RNA biosynthesis and elevated ROS levels in cancer cells, attenuating cell proliferation and tumour growth.
content.source_4: By enhancing AMPK phosphorylation through the LKB1 complex, 6PGD activity limited acetyl-CoA carboxylase function and lipogenesis; consequently, genetic ablation of 6PGD produced marked lipid accumulation in tumor models.
